scenarios.title: Add VLANs to a Switch (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Create VLANs, name them, and assign access ports on a Cisco Catalyst switch.
prerequisites: Basic CLI access to the switch (console or SSH)

steps.title: Enter global config and create VLANs
steps.notes: Some devices accept `name DATA` on the same line as `vlan 10` or as a following `name` command.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
vlan 10
 name DATA
!
vlan 20
 name VOICE
!
interface GigabitEthernet0/1
 switchport mode access
 switchport access vlan 10
 no shutdown

scenarios.title: Configure a Switch Using a Config File (Beginnerâ†’Intermediate)
scenarios.summary: Load a configuration file onto a managed switch and apply it safely, including hostname, management IP, and VLANs.
prerequisites: TFTP/FTP/USB access to the device or console access

steps.title: Backup current running config
steps.notes: Always backup before replacing config.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
hostname SWITCH-01
interface Vlan1
 ip address 192.168.1.2 255.255.255.0
 no shutdown

scenarios.title: Setup Trunking on a Switch (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Configure an 802.1Q trunk between two switches and allow VLANs 10 and 20.
scenarios.full_config_snippet:
interface GigabitEthernet0/24
 switchport trunk encapsulation dot1q
 switchport mode trunk
 switchport trunk allowed vlan 10,20
 no shutdown

scenarios.title: Secure Console and VTY Access (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Configure passwords for console, VTY (telnet/SSH), and privileged EXEC mode to secure device access.
objectives: Secure VTY lines for remote access

steps.title: Enter global configuration and set enable secret
steps.notes: Use 'enable secret' instead of 'enable password' for stronger MD5 hashing.

steps.title: Secure console line
steps.notes: exec-timeout sets idle timeout (5 minutes, 0 seconds). logging synchronous prevents command interruption by log messages.

steps.title: Secure VTY lines for remote access
steps.notes: Use 'transport input ssh' to allow only SSH. Use 'transport input telnet ssh' for both.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
enable secret CiscoSecure123
service password-encryption
line console 0
 password ConsolePass
 login
 exec-timeout 5 0
 logging synchronous
line vty 0 4
 password VtyPass
 login
 exec-timeout 10 0
 transport input ssh

scenarios.title: Configure SSH for Secure Remote Access (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Enable SSH on a Cisco device for secure remote management instead of Telnet.

steps.title: Configure hostname and domain name
steps.notes: Both hostname and domain name are required before generating RSA keys.

steps.title: Generate RSA keys
steps.notes: Use at least 2048 bits for security. This enables SSH version 2.

steps.title: Create local user and configure VTY
steps.notes: 'login local' uses local user database. 'privilege 15' grants full access.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
hostname R1
ip domain-name company.local
crypto key generate rsa modulus 2048
username admin privilege 15 secret AdminPass123
line vty 0 4
 login local
 transport input ssh
ip ssh version 2

scenarios.title: Configure Switch Port Security (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Enable port security to limit MAC addresses on a switchport and prevent unauthorized devices.

steps.title: Configure interface as access port
steps.notes: Port security only works on access ports, not trunk ports.

steps.title: Enable port security with sticky MAC
steps.notes: Violation modes: shutdown (disable port), restrict (drop + log), protect (drop silently).

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
interface GigabitEthernet0/1
 switchport mode access
 switchport access vlan 10
 switchport port-security
 switchport port-security maximum 2
 switchport port-security mac-address sticky
 switchport port-security violation shutdown
 no shutdown

scenarios.title: Configure CDP and LLDP for Device Discovery (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Enable and use CDP (Cisco Discovery Protocol) and LLDP (Link Layer Discovery Protocol) to discover neighboring devices.
prerequisites: Access to switch or router CLI

steps.title: Check and configure CDP
steps.notes: CDP is enabled by default on most Cisco devices. Use 'no cdp run' to disable globally.

steps.title: Enable and use LLDP
steps.notes: LLDP is industry-standard and works with non-Cisco devices. CDP is Cisco-proprietary.

scenarios.title: Configure Standard ACL to Filter Traffic (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Create and apply a standard access control list to permit or deny traffic based on source IP.

steps.title: Create standard ACL
steps.notes: Standard ACLs (1-99, 1300-1999) filter by source IP only. Implicit deny all at end.

steps.title: Apply ACL to interface
steps.notes: Apply standard ACLs close to the destination. 'in' filters incoming, 'out' filters outgoing.

steps.title: Verify ACL
steps.notes: Check hit counts on ACL entries and verify ACL is applied to the interface.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
access-list 10 permit 192.168.1.0 0.0.0.255
access-list 10 deny any log
interface GigabitEthernet0/1
 ip access-group 10 in

scenarios.title: Configure Extended ACL for Granular Filtering (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Create an extended ACL to filter traffic based on source, destination, and protocol/port.

steps.title: Create named extended ACL
steps.notes: Extended ACLs (100-199, 2000-2699) can filter by source, dest, protocol, and port.

steps.title: Apply ACL close to source
steps.notes: Apply extended ACLs close to the source to filter traffic early and save bandwidth.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
ip access-list extended WEB-FILTER
 permit tcp 192.168.1.0 0.0.0.255 any eq 80
 permit tcp 192.168.1.0 0.0.0.255 any eq 443
 deny ip any any log
interface GigabitEthernet0/0
 ip access-group WEB-FILTER in

scenarios.title: Configure NTP for Time Synchronization (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Set up NTP client to synchronize device time with an NTP server for accurate timestamps.

steps.title: Configure timezone and NTP
steps.notes: Use multiple NTP servers for redundancy. Google NTP: time.google.com (216.239.35.0).

steps.title: Verify NTP synchronization
steps.notes: NTP sync may take a few minutes. Look for '*' (synced) in associations output.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
clock timezone EST -5
clock summer-time EDT recurring
ntp server 216.239.35.0
ntp server 216.239.35.4

scenarios.title: Configure Syslog for Centralized Logging (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Send device logs to a centralized syslog server for monitoring and troubleshooting.

steps.title: Configure syslog server and settings
commands: service timestamps log datetime msec localtime show-timezone
steps.notes: Severity levels: emergencies(0) to debugging(7). 'informational' (6) is common for general monitoring.

steps.title: Verify logging configuration
steps.notes: Check buffer logs locally and verify messages are being sent to syslog server.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
logging host 192.168.1.100
logging trap informational
logging source-interface Loopback0
service timestamps log datetime msec localtime show-timezone

scenarios.title: Configure MOTD and Login Banners (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Set up banners to display legal warnings and identification when users connect to the device.
prerequisites: Console or remote access to device

steps.title: Configure device banners
steps.notes: Use a delimiter character (#) that won't appear in the banner text. MOTD shows first, then login banner.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
banner motd #
****************************************
*  AUTHORIZED ACCESS ONLY!             *
*  All activity is monitored.          *
****************************************
#
banner login #
Enter your credentials to continue.
#

scenarios.title: Configure Interface Speed and Duplex (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Manually set interface speed and duplex to troubleshoot or match specific requirements.

steps.title: Check current interface settings
steps.notes: Look for speed, duplex, and input/output errors in the output.

steps.title: Configure speed and duplex
steps.notes: Both ends must match. Mismatched duplex causes collisions and poor performance. Use 'speed auto' and 'duplex auto' for auto-negotiation.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
interface GigabitEthernet0/1
 speed 1000
 duplex full
 no shutdown

scenarios.title: Basic Interface Troubleshooting Commands (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Use essential show commands to diagnose interface and connectivity issues.

steps.title: Check interface status and errors
steps.notes: Look for 'up/up' status. Check CRC errors, input errors, collisions, and resets.

steps.title: Verify Layer 2 connectivity
steps.notes: MAC table shows learned addresses. CDP shows directly connected Cisco devices.

steps.title: Test Layer 3 connectivity
steps.notes: Ping tests reachability. Traceroute shows the path. Routing table shows known networks.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
! No configuration - these are verification commands
show ip interface brief
show interfaces GigabitEthernet0/1
show mac address-table
ping 192.168.1.1

scenarios.title: Save and Backup Device Configuration (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Learn to save running configuration and create backups using TFTP, FTP, or local storage.

steps.title: Save configuration locally
steps.notes: Both commands save running-config to NVRAM. 'write' is shorter but 'copy run start' is more explicit.

steps.title: Backup to TFTP server
steps.notes: Enter TFTP server IP and filename when prompted. Ensure TFTP server is reachable.

steps.title: View and compare configurations
steps.notes: Compare running and startup to see unsaved changes. Use 'show archive' if archive feature is configured.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
! Backup commands - not config
copy running-config startup-config
copy running-config tftp:

scenarios.title: Disable Unused Switch Ports (Beginner - Security)
scenarios.summary: Shutdown unused ports and assign them to a black-hole VLAN for security best practices.
prerequisites: Knowledge of which ports are in use

steps.title: Identify and document port usage
steps.notes: Ports showing 'notconnect' are candidates for shutdown. Document before making changes.

steps.title: Create black-hole VLAN and disable ports
steps.notes: Using a black-hole VLAN adds extra protection. Port must be manually enabled when needed.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
vlan 999
 name BLACKHOLE
interface range GigabitEthernet0/10 - 24
 switchport mode access
 switchport access vlan 999
 shutdown

scenarios.title: Configure Loopback Interface (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Create a loopback interface for router identification, management, and routing protocol stability.

steps.title: Create and configure loopback
steps.notes: Loopbacks are virtual interfaces that never go down. Use /32 mask. Common for OSPF router-id, BGP updates, management.

steps.title: Verify loopback
steps.notes: Loopback should show up/up. It's always up as long as the router is running.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
interface Loopback0
 ip address 1.1.1.1 255.255.255.255
 description Management-Loopback
 no shutdown

scenarios.title: Basic Password Recovery Concepts (Beginner)
scenarios.summary: Understand the password recovery process for Cisco routers and switches (conceptual overview).

steps.title: Password recovery overview
commands: ! This is conceptual - actual recovery requires console access
! Step 1: Power cycle and break into ROMMON (Ctrl+Break)
! Step 2: Change config-register to skip startup-config
steps.notes: 0x2142 tells router to ignore startup-config. Normal register is 0x2102.

steps.title: After boot - reset password
steps.notes: Copy startup to running preserves old config. Change password, restore register, save.

scenarios.full_config_snippet:
! Password recovery procedure - requires physical console access
! config-register 0x2142 to bypass startup-config
! config-register 0x2102 to restore normal boot
